The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. Subsections are redesignated and new subsections are added to accommodate these changes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. Subsections are redesignated and new subsections are added to accommodate these changes, including a new Flexible Fuel Hybrid Motor Vehicle Credit for taxpayers who place a new hybrid flexible fuel motor vehicle in service during the taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles. A credit amount for a motor vehicle placed in service by the taxpayer during the taxable year is determined according to a specific table. The credit amount for a vehicle based on city fuel economy ranges from $1,500 to $3,500, depending on the percentage increase compared to a comparable vehicle. The city fuel economy for determining the credit on a vehicle must be on an E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent basis, while the comparable vehicle's fuel economy is based on a gasoline gallon equivalent basis. The term 'new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle' refers to a qualified hybrid vehicle that can run on alternative fuel, gasoline, or any blend of both, certified by the EPA to achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol that is at least 125% of a comparable vehicle's city fuel economy.
